Message.Title: Intel targets low cost 3G handsets
Message.Msg: Most of the coverage of Intel's mobile efforts focus on processors for high end devices, but the company is not confining itself to the premium end any more. The first commercial handsets sporting Atom are decidedly midmarket (the Lava Xolo and the Orange San Diego), and now the firm is touting RF solutions for sub-$100 3G handsets. The latest product in the Smarti range, which Intel acquired with Infineon's wireless arm, integrates an HSPA RF transceiver with power amplifiers on a single 65nm die, and does not require a separate power management component. The Smarti UE2p will reduce the cost of adding 3G to a basic handset, says Intel, and could even be squeezed into modules for machine-to-machine connectivity. The chip will "simplify the product development and supply chain logistics with the reduction in component count and system complexity," according to Stefan Wolff, VP of the Intel Architecture Group. "This will allow our customers to introduce lower cost 3G handsets and support the transition of the M2M market segment toward 3G-based connected devices." Such launches indicate the importance of the Infineon purchase, often overshadowed by the work on mobile Atom. Intel is not yet offering fully integrated SoCs like Qualcomm's, but enhancement of the Smarti range, as well as ultra-low power Atom iterations, will pave the way to this - and will be essential for mass market phones and even low cost tablets. http://www.rethink-wireless.com/2012/07/30/intel-targets-low-cost-3g-handsets.htm

Message.Title: Intel Xeon Phi (B0 Stepping)
Message.Msg: WHOA !!!! A complete re-spin !!!! ------------------ "To every Intel insider, codenames P54C, Camino, Coppermine, Tejas and Larrabee carry special weight on the shoulders. In Intel's 44-year history, these products brought major disgrace to engineering" ...major disgrace !! INtel blew it on architecture... But hey, INtel fabs are ahead... "Intel has to play catch up - even though the company manufactures its Knights Corner ASIC in a leading manufacturing node (Intel 22nm Tri-Gate versus TSMC 28nm Planar)." INtel playing catch up with their architecture... but hey, INtel fabs are ahead... "clock speed of 600 MHz (57C/3GB and 57C/6GB) and 630+ MHz for the 60C/8GB and two 61C/8GB cards. Memory clock is now set at more realistic 5-5.5 billion transfers (1.25-1.37 GHz QDR), enabling memory bandwidth figures exceeding 300 GB/s. Top clock is now set at 1.1GHz for 57C/3GB and 57C/6GB parts, while the rest either works at 1.05 or 1.09GHz. The big news is the introduction of Turbo mode, but we weren't able to sniff out the exact clock achievable in Turbo mode for a low amount of active core." Turbo mode on old Pentium class CPUs... but hey, INtel fabs are ahead...
link http://vr-zone.com/articles/intel-xeon-phi-b0-stepping--the-knight-in-shining-armor-/16871.html

Topic.Title: Intel dividend increased. Yahoo needs to update.

Message.Msg: They also need to update the EX-DIV date which is Friday. That is one reason Intel is trading in such a narrow price range. Dividend arbitraging and the options market maker is preparing for big options volume tomorrow and Thursday.

I thought the B-step masks were the first production candidates. A-step masks would be nice to go into production with but the B-step masks are the first to incorporate patches, speed path adjustments and other changes found by generating the first A-step silicon. A-step is usually the demo silicon. That is what Haswell is on. I think that are on the E-step masks for some of the new Ivy Bridge products. I am surprised that anyone would get so excited about B-step. A B-step is hardly a complete revision.
